citation.article-title: Corynebacterium camporealensis sp. nov., associated with subclinical mastitis in sheep

p.s: Description of Corynebacterium camporealensis sp. nov.
Corynebacterium camporealensis (campo.real.en'sis. M.L. adj. pertaining to Campo Real, Madrid, Spain)
The description is based on the examination of the four strains included in this study.
Strains consist of non-motile pleomorphic rods that are Gram-positive, and non-spore-forming.
Cells occur singly or are arranged in palisades or V-shaped forms.
Non-haemolytic colonies are circular (1-2 mm in diameter), slightly convex, smooth and with a creamy consistency, after 48 h incubation at 37 °C in blood agar.
They are nonlipophilic and exhibit slight growth under anaerobic conditions.
Aesculin, urea and gelatin are not hydrolysed.
Acetoin and indole are not produced.
Acid is produced from glucose, but not from ribose, xylose, mannitol, lactose, maltose, sucrose and glycogen.
Pyrazinamidase, alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C5), lipase (C14), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase and cystine arylamidase are produced.

Pyrrolidonyl-arylamidase, acid phosphatase, β-glucuronidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, α-mannosidase, α-fucosidase and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, trypsin and chymotrypsin are not produced.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid.
The type strain is CRS-51T and it has been deposited in the Spanish Type Culture Collection as strain CECT 4897T.
The type strain was isolated in Campo Real, Spain, from milk of a sheep affected with subclinical mastitis.
